pullRequest.body:
We define [polynomial sequences](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polynomial_sequence) -- that is, sequences of polynomials where the `i`th polynomial has degree `i`.

We do not yet refactor any existing polynomial sequences to go via this proof (e.g. for the usual monomial basis which has its own proof already in Mathlib).
    
Co-authored-by: Aaron Hill <aa1ronham@gmail.com>
Co-authored-by: Julian Berman <Julian@GrayVines.com>
Co-authored-by: Matej Penciak <matej.penciak@gmail.com>
Co-authored-by: Austin Letson <waustinletson@gmail.com>

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> List.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

nodes.body:
### PR summary [c572510475](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/20846/commits/c572510475c1704f306468429e60f786ac014ee1)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.Algebra.Polynomial.Sequence` (new file)|1001|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ Sequence`
`+ basis`
`+ basis_degree_eq`
`+ basis_eq_self`
`+ basis_natDegree_eq`
`+ coeFun`
`+ degree_eq`
`+ degree_inj`
`+ degree_ne`
`+ degree_smul_of_isRightRegular_leadingCoeff`
`+ foo`
`+ linearIndependent`
`+ natDegree_eq`
`+ natDegree_ne`
`+ ne_zero`
`+ span`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>
Thanks!
Thanks!
This PR is nice! Could you add some API for the basis please? At least `S.basis hCoeff i = S i`.

I added the specific one you suggested -- I couldn't immediately think of others nor find another basis whose API I could cargo cult (or learn what typically is provided).

If you have any other suggestions please feel free to teach me!

(Or otherwise at some point we may try to formalize some change-of-basis theorems about changing between polynomial sequence bases and then maybe it'll be obvious what API we need ourselves?)

Thanks! I guess you can also add a lemma giving the degree: `(S.basis hCoeff i).degree = i`, and equivalents for `natDegree_eq` and `degree_ne_degree`. As your objects have certain properties and are then wrapped in the basis I figure it is simpler to transfer these properties to the element of the basis directly. Of course it's hard to anticipate what will be needed. As you say, the best way to find out is to use it!

When referring to a definition like `IsRightRegular`, we usually don't abbreviate it in the name, and segments should go in outer-inner order
```suggestion
theorem degree_smul_of_isRightRegular_leadingCoeff {k : R} (hk: k  0)
```

```suggestion
/-- Make `S i` mean `S.elems' i`. -/
```
or rename the field
Do we want a variant of this lemma with `Function.Injective`, maybe?
Added (hopefully correctly).
This proof doesn't immediately generalize, but is this true over semirings?
I wasn't sure, and I saw lots of the linear independence API being generalized the last few weeks to Semirings. I'll look again to see if perhaps now I can find something that works.

```suggestion
    refine degree_ne_bot.mp ?_ eqzero |>.elim
```

I think this is more sensible to state as
```suggestion
    span R (Set.range S) =  := by
```

That would have been what I expected too, but this is how it's spelled in `Basis.mk`'s argument, and I assumed whatever reasoning applied there applied elsewhere (I guess because `\le` is easier to prove than `\eq` or something?) And then I saw other span API also use this kind of spelling.

Or are you aware of all that and telling me it's still better to phrase the standalone lemma this way?

I once wrote a lemma with the conclusion being `  ...` and was told that `... = ` was better because it allows to rewrite directly. I think the idea of `  ...` is as you said that it allows to only prove one inequality, but `eq_top_iff` can help with that so I think it's better (and more paper math friendly) to write `... = `.
Aha! The rewrite thing makes sense -- though I'm left still wondering then why `Basis.mk` doesn't take a proof of `=`. But thanks, that makes enough sense for now to me!

```suggestion
  by_cases p_ne_zero : P = 0
   simp [p_ne_zero]
```

pullRequest.title: feat(Polynomial): polynomial sequences are bases for R[X]
